Award.AbstractNarration:
A homogeneous space is a geometric object that manifests a continuous family of symmetries. Dynamics of flows on homogeneous spaces are related to many natural problems in number theory and geometry. Traditionally, the homogeneous spaces of interest in most studies have finite volume. However, it has recently been discovered that the dynamics on homogeneous spaces of infinite volume also arise in many natural problems such as Apollonian circle packings and in building efficient networks. This proposal will investigate this rich topic.

The proposal deals with dynamics on infinite homogeneous spaces, which turns out to yield quite a rich theory and has several deep and striking applications. The proposed study involves new interactions between hyperbolic geometry, Kleinian groups, ergodic theory, and number theory. Investigating this new territory requires many new ideas both from geometry and dynamics, and opens up new interactions between these fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a world of "finite volume",  flows have to be recurrent as there is not too much space to run away. On the other hand, in the world of infinite volume, there are so much more possibilities in principle, and flows comes back to where it started much less frequently than the finite volume case. This lack of recurrence is usually the main source of  difficulty in the study dynamics and rigidity in manifolds of infinite volume.

In joint work with McMullen, and Mohammadi, we have understood how the topology and geometry of hyperbolic 3-manifolds of infinite volume influence the recurrence of unipotent flows. Using this understanding, we obtained topological rigidity results for geodesic planes on hyperbolic manifolds of infinite volume. Such a result was known previously only for the finite volume case, and hence only for countably many hyperbolic manifolds. Our rigidity theorem applies to an uncountably many hyperbolic manifolds, and it is the first such result.

 

We have given many lectures on this work including the lecture series in the Fields institute summer school, and Namboodiri lecture series at University of Chicago. We have also given a lecture for several hundread high school students in Korea in the occasion of Ho-Am prize in Science lecture.

We are also advising four graduate students and two postdoctoral fellows.
